channel.title: R Markdown on Steven Koski's Blog
channel.description: Recent content in R Markdown on Steven Koski's Blog

item.title: A Brief Introduction to Bar Plots
item.description: #Hair color is an atrribute with different levels for each of the hair colors. #All of these are called factors in this termonology. Color of our eyes, or hair are these factors standing<-c("junior","freshmen","junior","Sophmore","Senior") # class(standing) Allows you to check what variable is made up of... in this case characters #Store the standing back into itself as this new factor version standing<-factor(standing,levels=c("freshmen","sophmores","junior","senior")) #You must order the table how YOU want it to be done^

item.title: An Introduction to Histograms
item.description: This next chunk of code will show the basics of creating a Simple Bar graph in Rstudio to show data in a different possible way. query<-"SELECT weight FROM Master" #Good example of storing all the data into a variable that you #Can use elsewhere in your code result<-sqldf(query) #Issue with all clors default making it this bright pink ggplot()+ geom_histogram(data=result,aes(x=weight),color="blue",fill="white",bins=50)+ ggtitle("Body-Weight of the fat baseball players") ## Warning: Removed 854 rows containing non-finite values (stat_bin).

item.title: Time Series
item.description: This is a scatterplot that has two columns of numerical data and one represents time wile the oher reperesents different points of data query<-"SELECT yearID,HR FROM Batting WHERE playerID='ruthba01'" result<-sqldf(query) ggplot()+ geom_point(data=result,aes(x=yearID,y=HR))+ geom_line(data=result,aes(x=yearID,y=HR))+ ggtitle("Frequency of high-magnitude earthquakes per year")+ xlab("Year")+ ylab("Ammount per year")

item.title: 9.29.2017 Scatterplots
item.description: This next code is an example of a scatterplot we learned in class. It gathers all the data and plots thm as dots on a graph to make it easier to visualize the data. We also draw lines between each of the data points to make it easier to visualize how the points are ordered. #This is a scatterplot that has two columns of numerical data and one #represents time wile the other reperesents different points of data query<-"SELECT yearID,HR FROM Batting WHERE playerID='ruthba01'" result<-sqldf(query) ggplot()+ geom_point(data=result,aes(x=yearID,y=HR))+ geom_line(data=result,aes(x=yearID,y=HR))+ ggtitle("Home Runs Per Year for Babe Ruth")+ xlab("Year")+ ylab("Home Runs")

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.
